awd_titl_txt: Studies of Nuclear Reactions and Stucture
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the experimental nuclear physics group at Florida State University and the operation of the John D. Fox Superconducting Accelerator Laboratory, as well as other work at national user laboratories.  The experiments include studies of nuclear reactions and decays that play key roles in all stages of stellar processes.  Other experiments focus on understanding where the chemical elements come from and how they evolved and ordered themselves into nuclear shell structures.    The group will also exploit heavy ion collisions at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) to investigate how visible matter came into being and how it evolved from a quark-gluon plasma.  Much of this program is aligned to address fundamental questions outlined in the 2015 Long Range Plan for Nuclear Science.  The broader societal impacts of this project lie in the education and training of undergraduate and graduate students in a hands-on environment. Because of the students' training and hands-on work with high tech equipment in a forefront nuclear physics laboratory, FSU graduates are in high demand and now serve in key roles in homeland security, national defense, high-tech industry, leading edge research, and STEM education.  The group also is active in supporting and strengthening local school systems.  

The John D. Fox accelerator laboratory focuses on programs in nuclear structure physics through particle and gamma-ray spectroscopy and nuclear astrophysics with radioactive beams produced in flight by the RESOLUT facility. In addition, the newly installed Super-Enge Split-Pole Spectrograph (SE-SPS) at the FSU accelerator is re-establishing a nationally unique resource for high-resolution spectroscopy of light- and heavy-ion reactions.  The group will have a new research focus on the nuclear physics of unbound states and the super-radiance mechanism in light nuclei. Another new initiative is the development of a novel Multi-Sample Ion Chamber (FSU-MUSIC) active-target detector, to be used in the measurement of fusion cross-sections between exotic nuclei and at low energy. The detector will be combined with position-resolving silicon-detectors such that elastic and inelastic scattering, transfer-reactions and fusion can be measured simultaneously, in an effort to unravel the various contributions to the fusion mechanism at low energies. Finally, the ANASEN active-target detector is a leading detector system for reactions of astrophysical interest at FSU and also in two recent experiments at the re-accelerated beam facility REA-3 of the NSCL. This is an example of how the development of a new detector technology and methods at the local laboratory creates scientific opportunity at national facilities and is a model for the future role of the laboratory in the era of FRIB.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the hands-on training in experimental nuclear physics for over a dozen Ph.D. students and a number of undergraduate physics majors. During the period Brittany Abromeit, Jonathan Barron, Nabin Rijal, Rebeca Lubna, Maria Anastasiou, Kalisa Villafana, Elizabeth Rubino and, after the end of the regular grant period, Krista Smith, Nathan Gerken and Ben Asher received Ph.D. degrees based on research supported by this grant and are now employed in research, homeland security, education, and industry.  
The grant supported the operation and improvement of the John D. Fox accelerator laboratory at Florida State University. A significant new capability at the laboratory was achieved by commissioning the newly-installed large "split-pole" magnetic spectrograph and auxiliary equipment around it. These precision instruments now constitute a unique system to perform measurements of nuclear reactions and nuclear excitation spectra.  Our facilities attract outside experimenters from other universities, in particular contributing to the Ph.D. research projects at Louisiana State University, undergraduate research opportunities.
The FSU laboratory supports strong programs studying the excitation spectrum of atomic nuclei. In particular, our almost world-unique radioactive Carbon-14 beam was used for a number of experiments detecting particle and gamma emission from hard to produce neutron-rich nuclei and study them in detail and towards higher excitation energies. Experimental data collected by our group at FSU and other experimental facilities allowed for a systematic description of nuclear excitations across shell-boundaries, resulting in the ?FSU? shell model interaction, which makes more reliable predictions for exotic, neutron-rich nuclei, which will soon be accessible at the Facility for Rare Ion Beams.  
Another focus of the research supported by this grant was on experiments with short-lived radioactive beams, which are often used to study nuclear reactions with importance to understand astrophysical processes. The reactions between the radioactive isotope beryllium-7 and deuterium were measured at the FSU laboratory, allowing for the first time to determine the impact of this reaction on the synthesis of Lithium during the Big Bang. The group also developed the Encore detector system, which was used to determine the low-energy fusion reactions of exotic, short-lived nuclei, such as Flourine-17. Furthermore, the FSU group pioneered measuring the reactions of nuclei in isomeric states, in particular the isomeric state of the Sodium-24 isotope, which only lives for 21 milliseconds. Its structure and reactions were analyzed for their contribution to stellar nucleosynthesis.  
The FSU group analyzed heavy-ion reactions at the RHIC facility at Brookhaven National Laboratory,  measurement of the J/Psi nuclear modification factor in p+Au and 3He+Au collisions. They demonstrate that the effects of final state interactions in these light systems on J/ψ production are very small, and they provide a comprehensive data set for detailed studies of initial state effects.
